node.text:
Dr. George Papanicolaou joined me on The Doctor’s Farmacy to talk about the relationship between your immune system and the gut. We also discuss hyperthyroidism, Graves Disease, and how we work with patients to treat the root causes of these issues.⁣
⁣
You can listen to the full episode titled, "A Root Cause Approach to Hyperthyroidism and Grave’s Disease," on your favorite podcast app.

node.text:
The thyroid gland is a small gland located in your neck that is part of your endocrine or hormonal system. It produces two major thyroid hormones, and the overproduction of these hormones is termed hyperthyroidism. Sixty to seventy percent of individuals with hyperthyroidism suffer from an autoimmune condition called Graves’ disease. So, what is driving these issues and how can that information be used to treat the root causes of hyperthyroidism and Graves’ disease?⁣
⁣
In this episode, Dr. Hyman sits down with Dr. George Papanicolaou to discuss how they work with patients to treat the root causes of hyperthyroidism and Graves’ disease. They discuss topics including environmental toxin exposure, the role of gut health in driving autoimmune disease, using thyroid hormone replacement therapy, and much more.⁣
⁣
George Papanicolaou is a graduate of the Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine and is Board Certified in Family Medicine from Abington Memorial Hospital. He is also an Institute for Functional Medicine Practitioner. In 2000, he founded Cornerstone Family Practice in Rowley, MA. He practiced with a philosophy centered on personal relationships and treating the whole person, not just not the disease. He called that philosophy “Whole Life Wellness”. Over time as the healthcare system made it harder for patients to receive this kind of personal care Dr. Papanicolaou decided a change was needed. He began training in Functional Medicine through the Institute of Functional Medicine. In 2015, he established Cornerstone Personal Health – a practice dedicated entirely to Functional Medicine. Dr. Papanicolaou joined The UltraWellness Center in 2017.⁣
⁣
This episode is sponsored by Rupa Health and Paleovalley.⁣
⁣
Rupa Health is a place for Functional Medicine practitioners to access more than 2,000 specialty lab tests from over 20 labs like DUTCH, Vibrant America, Genova, Great Plains, and more. You can check out a free live demo with a Q&A or create an account at RupaHealth.com. ⁣
⁣
Paleovalley is offering 15% off your entire first order. Just go to paleovalley.com/hyman to check out all their clean Paleo products and take advantage of this deal.

node.title: A Root Cause Approach to Hyperthyroidism and Graves’ Disease

node.text:
My guest on this week’s episode of The Doctor’s Farmacy, Fred Provenza, is an incredible resource for understanding the link between soil organisms, plant nutrient profiles, and animal and human health. ⁣
⁣
I was fascinated at the concept that the microbiome of our soils doesn’t just influence the nutrients of plants, but that the plants help determine that microbiome. This is why monoculture is so devastating—Fred and I dig into this relationship and why diversity, just like for our human diets, is essential for healthy soils and healthy animals. ⁣
⁣
You can listen to the full episode titled, “How The Intelligence Of Plants and Animals Can Help Us Reclaim Our Health,” on your favorite podcast.⁣

node.title: Why Monocrop Culture Is Bad For Health

node.text:
In a healthy body, the process of detoxification runs smoothly. When our detoxification system becomes overwhelmed and overloaded, we start developing symptoms and get sick. This is why supporting our innate detoxification system is a vital component of full body health. ⁣
⁣
In this mini-episode, Dr. Hyman speaks with his colleagues at The UltraWellness Center about how proper detoxification starts with our diets. They explore how food and lifestyle practices can be used to enhance detoxification and support our overall health. ⁣
⁣
Maggie Ward, MS, RD, LDN is the Nutrition Director at The UltraWellness Center. Much of her focus is on food allergies, digestive disorders, inflammatory conditions, Pediatrics and Sports Nutrition. 
 ⁣
Dr. LePine graduated from Dartmouth Medical School and is Board Certified in Internal Medicine, specializing in Integrative Functional Medicine. He is an Institute for Functional Medicine Certified Practitioner. Dr. LePine’s focus at The UltraWellness Center is to help his patients achieve optimal health and vitality by restoring the natural balance to both the mind and the body. 
 ⁣
@elizabethbohammd is a physician and nutritionist who practices Functional Medicine at The UltraWellness Center in Lenox, MA. Through her practice and lecturing she has helped thousands of people achieve their goals of optimum health and wellness. 
⁣
This episode is brought to you by Athletic Greens. Athletic Greens is offering Doctor’s Farmacy listeners a full year supply of their Vitamin D3/K2 Liquid Formula free with your first purchase, plus 5 free travel packs. Just go to athleticgreens.com/hyman to take advantage of this great offer.⁣

node.title: What To Eat And Do To Promote Detoxification

node.text:
Phytochemicals are one of the most important aspects of nutrition that most people have never heard of. Fred Provenza joined me on The Doctor’s Farmacy to explain how they influence the flavor and medicinal properties of our food, what animals and children can teach us about eating for phytochemicals diversity, and why we’re looking for love in all the wrong places when it comes to the Standard American Diet. ⁣
⁣
You can listen to the full episode titled, “How The Intelligence Of Plants and Animals Can Help Us Reclaim Our Health,” on your favorite podcast.⁣

node.title: This Is The Purpose Of Food Cravings

node.text:
If we take the time to be quiet, still, and curious, there’s an immeasurable amount of knowledge to be gained from our natural surroundings. In watching grazing animals and their food choices, we see they know how to personalize their nutritional intake to eat plants that match their exact needs. Though many of us have lost our innate wisdom to eat intuitively, upping our intake of phytochemicals and reducing processed foods means we can recalibrate our cravings to lean towards what we truly need. Vitamins and minerals often get most of the attention when it comes to eating for nutrient density, but phytochemicals are the real hidden talent for optimizing plant, animal, and human health. Unfortunately, modern agriculture has actually damaged the phytochemical richness of our food, by breeding for yield, appearance, and hardiness. I enjoyed sitting down with Fred Provenza in this episode of The Doctor’s Farmacy to talk about all this and so much more. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Fred grew up in Salida, Colorado, working on a ranch and attending school in Wildlife⁣⁣ Biology at Colorado State University. He is professor emeritus of Behavioral Ecology in the⁣⁣ Department of Wildland Resources at Utah State University where he worked for 35 years,⁣⁣ directing an award-winning research group that pioneered an understanding of how learning⁣⁣ influences foraging behavior and how behavior links soil, plants, herbivores, and humans. He is the author of three books, including his latest, Nourishment: What Animals Can Teach Us about⁣⁣ Rediscovering Our Nutritional Wisdom.
⁣⁣
This episode is brought to you by Joovv, BiOptimizers, and Primal Kitchen.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Joovv is offering Doctor’s Farmacy listeners an exclusive discount on Joovv’s Generation 3.0 devices. Just go to Joovv.com/farmacy and use the code FARMACY. Some exclusions do apply. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Right now, BiOptimizers is offering Doctor’s Farmacy listeners 10% off your Magnesium Breakthrough order. Just go to magbreakthrough.com/hyman and use code HYMAN10 to receive this amazing offer.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Right now, Primal Kitchen is offering my community 20% off. Just go to primalkitchen.com and use the code DRHYMAN20 at checkout.⁣⁣

He is the author of three books, including his latest book, Nourishment: What Animals Can Teach Us about⁣ Rediscovering Our Nutritional Wisdom.
⁣
This episode is brought to you by Joovv, BiOptimizers, and Primal Kitchen.⁣
⁣
Joovv is offering Doctor’s Farmacy listeners an exclusive discount on Joovv’s Generation 3.0 devices. Just go to Joovv.com/farmacy and use the code FARMACY. Some exclusions do apply. ⁣
⁣
Right now, BiOptimizers is offering Doctor’s Farmacy listeners 10% off your Magnesium Breakthrough order. Just go to magbreakthrough.com/hyman and use code HYMAN10 to receive this amazing offer.⁣
⁣
Right now, Primal Kitchen is offering my community 20% off. Just go to primalkitchen.com and use the code DRHYMAN20 at checkout.⁣

Dr. Cindy Geyer joined me on The Doctor’s Farmacy to talk about commonly unconsidered contributing factors to heart disease, such as hormonal imbalances, low gut microbiome diversity, and much more.

Listen to the full episode titled, "Prevent And Reverse Heart Disease Using Functional Medicine," on your favorite podcast app.

node.title: Heart Disease Is A Hormonal & Inflammation Issue

node.text:
Dr. George Papanicolaou joined me on The Doctor’s Farmacy to talk about the relationship between your immune system and the gut. We also discuss hyperthyroidism, Graves Disease, and how we work with patients to treat the root causes of these issues.⁣
⁣
You can listen to the full episode titled, "A Root Cause Approach to Hyperthyroidism and Grave’s Disease," on your favorite podcast app.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'You may be surprised to learn that having a parasite, in and of itself, is not necessarily a bad thing. In fact, our gut microbiome is made up more than 500 different species of microbes, including various types of bacteria, fungi, parasites, and viruses. Some of them help us, but others are harmful. of @DRMARKHYMAN'.

node.text:
Parasitic infection can result in an individual experiencing a range of symptoms from digestive issues to muscle ache, joint pain, skin rashes, and more; it can also signal issues with a weakened immune system. ⁣⁣⁠
⁣⁣⁠
In a recent episode of The Doctor’s Farmacy, I sat down with Dr. George Papanicolaou to discuss how parasites can influence our overall health, and why they sometimes trigger autoimmune disease, gut imbalance, and much more.⁣⁣⁠
⁣⁣⁠
Take a listen through the link in my bio. ⁣⁣⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Signs your cells aren't getting the fats they need Dry, itchy, scaling, or flaking skin Soft, cracked, or brittle nails Hard earwax Tiny bumps on the backs of your arms or torso Achy, stiff joints @DRMARKHYMAN'.

node.text:
Your body sends signals when it’s not getting enough good fats. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
That’s because the body uses the fat you eat to build cell walls. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
You have more than 10 trillion cells in your body, and every single one of them needs high-quality fat.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
The higher-quality the fat you eat, the better your brain will function. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I eat fat with every meal, and I’ve never felt better. The right fats can improve your mood, skin, hair, and nails, while protecting you against Type 2 diabetes, dementia, cancer, and much more.⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Among my favorite sources of fat include:⁣⁣⁣⁣
Avocados⁣⁣⁣⁣
Nuts & seeds⁣⁣⁣⁣
Fatty fish that are rich in omega-3 fats⁣⁣⁣⁣
Extra virgin olive oil ⁣⁣⁣⁣
Grass-fed or sustainably raised animal products ⁣⁣⁣

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021 tagging @ayeletmenashe. May be an image of chow mein and text that says 'Swipe Left to See My Olive Oil and Herb Gluten-Free Pasta with Quinoa Breadcrumbs- @DRMARKHYMAN'.

node.text: With the right ingredients, you can feel good about enjoying the occasional pasta dish. This one avoids inflammatory gluten and is generously drizzled with olive oil and studded with olives, two superstar ingredients for heart health. Olives and their oil are rich sources of monounsaturated fats and antioxidants and have been found to reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021 tagging @ayeletmenashe. May be an image of chow mein and text that says 'Swipe Left to See My Olive Oil and Herb Gluten-Free Pasta with Quinoa Breadcrumbs- @DRMARKHYMAN'.

Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Ingredients: 1/3 cup quinoa, rinsed and drained 2/3 cups of water 3 garlio cloves, minced 1/4 teaspoon sea salt 1 cup Italian parsley, minced 1/2 cup dill weed, minced 1/3 cup Castelvetrano olives, pitted and halved 1 bunch broccoli rabe, stems chopped, eaves and florets left whole 8 ounces preferred gluten-free pasta (such as quinoa pasta) 10 anchovy fillets @DRMARKHYMAN'.

Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Ingredients: 1 pasture-raised egg yolk 1 large lemon, zested and juiced 1/2 teaspoon red chili flakes 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper 1/2 cup olive oil Salt to taste (optional) Step 1: Begin by making the quinoa breadcrumbs. In a small saucepan, bring water to boil and add quinoa. Lower heat and cook, covered, for 15 minutes until water is absorbed and quinoa is fluffy. Remove from heat. @DRMARKHYMAN'.
Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021. May be an image of food and indoor.

Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Step 2: Preheat the oven to 400°F and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Mince garlic and place in a small bowl along with sea salt. Step 3: Add parsley, dill, and olives to a separate small bowl, mix together, and set aside. Step 4: Transfer quinoa to the prepared baking sheet. Spread quinoa in an even layer and bake for 25 minutes stirring every 5 to 10 minutes to avoid the quinoa from burning. @DRMARKHYMAN'.
Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021. May be an image of food and indoor.

Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Step 5: When quinoa is toasted and golden, remove from the oven and transfer to the bowl with garlic and salt. Stir to combine. Step 6: In a large pot, boil water and cook the pasta according to the brand's instructions. Chop broccoli rabe and add to the boiling pot 3 minutes before the pasta is ready. Drain pasta and broccoli rabe, but reserve 1/2 cup of the cooking liquid. @DRMARKHYMAN'.
Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021.

Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Step 7: Meanwhile, mash anchovies to a paste using the side of a knife. Add to a large mixing bowl with the egg yolk, lemon juice, zest, chili flakes, black pepper, and olive oil, and mix well to incorporate. Step 8: Add pasta and broccoli rabe into that large bowl with the egg mixture, along with the reserved pasta liquid, and mix well. Fold the herb and olive mixture the pasta bowl and add more salt to taste. Serve immediately. into @DRMARKHYMAN'.
Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 19, 2021. May be an image of food and indoor.

node.text:
The thyroid gland is a small gland located in your neck that is part of your endocrine or hormonal system. It produces two major thyroid hormones, and the overproduction of these hormones is termed hyperthyroidism. Sixty to seventy percent of individuals with hyperthyroidism suffer from an autoimmune condition called Graves’ disease. So, what is driving these issues and how can that information be used to treat the root causes of hyperthyroidism and Graves’ disease?⁣
⁣
In this episode, Dr. Hyman sits down with Dr. George Papanicolaou to discuss how they work with patients to treat the root causes of hyperthyroidism and Graves’ disease. They discuss topics including environmental toxin exposure, the role of gut health in driving autoimmune disease, using thyroid hormone replacement therapy, and much more.⁣
⁣
George Papanicolaou is a graduate of the Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine and is Board Certified in Family Medicine from Abington Memorial Hospital. He is also an Institute for Functional Medicine Practitioner. In 2000, he founded Cornerstone Family Practice in Rowley, MA. He practiced with a philosophy centered on personal relationships and treating the whole person, not just not the disease. He called that philosophy “Whole Life Wellness”. Over time as the healthcare system made it harder for patients to receive this kind of personal care Dr. Papanicolaou decided a change was needed. He began training in Functional Medicine through the Institute of Functional Medicine. In 2015, he established Cornerstone Personal Health – a practice dedicated entirely to Functional Medicine. Dr. Papanicolaou joined The UltraWellness Center in 2017.⁣
⁣
This episode is sponsored by Rupa Health and Paleovalley.⁣
⁣
Rupa Health is a place for Functional Medicine practitioners to access more than 2,000 specialty lab tests from over 20 labs like DUTCH, Vibrant America, Genova, Great Plains, and more. You can check out a free live demo with a Q&A or create an account at RupaHealth.com. ⁣
⁣
Paleovalley is offering 15% off your entire first order. Just go to paleovalley.com/hyman to check out all their clean Paleo products and take advantage of this deal.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The single biggest hormonal disorder we face is insulin resistance. One in two Americans has pre-diabetes or type 2 diabetes and 75% are overweight-all all suffering from too much insulin, the result of the mountains of sugar and flour we consume. @DRMARKHYMAN'.

node.text:
That insulin in turn creates a domino effect. It drives all those excess calories into fat cells that produce messengers that increase hunger, slow metabolism, prevent fat burning, and spike inflammation. ⁣
⁣
In women too much insulin turns estrogen into testosterone. The result is something misleadingly called polycystic ovarian syndrome. It is not an ovarian problem; it is a dietary problem. The extra testosterone in women causes hair loss, facial hair, acne, and infertility. ⁣
⁣
In men the testosterone gets converted to estrogen, which is why men with big bellies often have man boobs, low testosterone, impotence, and loss of hair on their bodies. In other words, they become more like women. ⁣
⁣
The same high sugar and starch diet also spikes the hormone cortisol. When you eat a sugar laden diet, your body literally perceives it as a stress, just like when a tiger chases you. Adrenaline and cortisol increase, worsening insulin resistance and increasing cravings for sugar and starch. ⁣
⁣
The cure: A whole foods, good fat, plant rich, fiber rich, low glycemic, and phytonutrient rich diet. This is what I call the Pegan Diet. ⁣
⁣
Our hormones are highly influenced by what we eat. The biggest factor impacting your communication system is reversing insulin resistance. The good news is that reversing insulin resistance starts at home, with your next bite!⁣

node.text:
My guest on this week’s episode of The Doctor’s Farmacy, Fred Provenza, is an incredible resource for understanding the link between soil organisms, plant nutrient profiles, and animal and human health. ⁣
⁣
I was fascinated at the concept that the microbiome of our soils doesn’t just influence the nutrients of plants, but that the plants help determine that microbiome. This is why monoculture is so devastating—Fred and I dig into this relationship and why diversity, just like for our human diets, is essential for healthy soils and healthy animals. ⁣
⁣
You can listen to the full episode titled, “How The Intelligence Of Plants and Animals Can Help Us Reclaim Our Health,” on your favorite podcast.⁣

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 17, 2021. May be a Twitter screenshot of 1 person and text that says 'Mark Hyman, M.D. @drmarkhyman Your stem cells are wired to your brain and help you repair and regenerate. But they only turn on and make new brain cells when you relax.'.

node.text:
And I don't mean sipping a glass of Chardonnay while watching TV or practicing retail therapy. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
In school, we all learned how to read and write, but we never learned how to use our minds to help us with the most important survival skills of all: staying happy and healthy! Research has shown over and over again that learning to relax is one of the most important keys to long-term health and vitality. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
To engage the powerful forces of the mind on the body, you must DO something. Learn how to ACTIVELY relax. ⁣⁣
⁣
Whether you practice deep breathing or take a simple leisurely walk, find an active relaxation that works for you and do it. Here are a few more ideas on how to push your pause button:⠀⁣⁣
⁣⁣
1) Make choices that make your life balanced — practice saying “NO” to others and “YES” to yourself.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
2) Try yoga or meditation.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
3) Get enough sleep.⁣
⁣⁣
4) Eat whole foods that decrease the stress response.⁣

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Using the lens of Functional Medicine, we can see that disease is so much more than its location. With inflammation smoldering throughout the body in many people, we need to zero in on the immune system, how it's functioning, and what factors are negatively impacting it. @DRMARKHYMAN'.

node.text:
We’re in an exciting time for research in this area, as we continue to learn how to fix the problems behind an aging immune system.⁣⁠
⁣⁠
I talked about this topic with my close friend, @drjeffreybland, in a recent episode of The Doctor’s Farmacy. We dove into how the immune system works and why we don’t want to “boost” it, but actually modulate it. He explained the importance of bone marrow and stem cell production and how when our environment damages this process (through things like toxins, poor diet, lack of sleep, etc.) the immune system becomes dysregulated and the door opens for chronic disease.⁣⁠
⁣⁠
Listen through the link in my bio.⁣⁠

This is part one of my conversation with Alan. You can watch part two by tapping on the IGTV tab on my profile.
 
From July 16th-July 18th, Comvita is offering my community 20% off their purchase with code DRHYMAN20. Redeem this offer at comvita.com. @ComvitaUSA #sponsored

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Mark Hyman, M.D. on July 16, 2021. May be a Twitter screenshot of 1 person and text that says 'Mark Hyman, M.D. @drmarkhyman Did you know that 40% of the food in our kitchens is thrown into the trash? If food waste were a country, it would be the third-largest emitter of greenhouse gases after the United States and China.'.

node.text:
Produce thrown in the garbage emits more than 3 times as much methane as factory-farmed livestock. ⁣
⁣
Microplastics that come from waste thrown into the ocean end up in our fish, seafood, and even things like tea, salt, beer, bottled and tap water, and more. Does this mean we should panic? ⁣
⁣
No. It means we need to live as sustainably as possible, and part of that includes how we grow, consume, and discard food and food-related products. ⁣
⁣
I want to challenge you to minimize food waste in your own home. I do this by making WIF meals. What is WIF? It means “Whatever is in the Fridge.” You might be surprised at the beautiful creations that you make with what is left in the fridge. I love to create beautiful stir-fries and interesting salads with what’s left in my fridge.⁣
⁣
Another important thing to remember when you’re grocery shopping is to only buy what you really need. These are just two of the many ways we can reduce food waste and reduce the burden of global warming. ⁣
⁣
Remember, whatever diet we choose (vegan, vegetarian, Paleo, and everything in between), we can move toward a regenerative and protective way of eating — for ourselves and the planet. ⁣
⁣
To learn more about the connection between food and climate change, check out my book Food Fix. Find more information at FoodFixBook.com⁣
